reviewText:
OK, first of all, this game is not really an RPG. I know it reads up there on the genre description here on Steam, but this game is more of an Action RPG then anything else.

So, basically you enter this world where humans are fighting against demons and vice versa. In your first playthrough you start playing on the Light campaign, as one of the humans. The controls function like any other RPG, except here the combat is more fast paced. You don't go around and do quests and there is very little dialog. What you do is basically kill everything you see, and collect as much gold as you can. With the gold you collect, you can equip better weapons, armor, and bring more potions with you each time. There are quite a lot of races/classes that you gain as you play (some by completing levels, and some are special classes that you get after collecting all of the gold in the game).

The game itself is fun. It's obviously not a modern game. The graphics are dated, but they're not ugly or anything. The soundtrack is lacking, with only a few songs that you keep hearing over and over, but hey, at least they're good. The gameplay is simple and intuitive, but I have to warn you that the hitboxes are very small, and the game can be a bit difficult sometimes. I finished the game on medium but even then I had to replay most levels quite a few times. After you finish the game for the first time, you can play the game now on the Dark campaign and get a different perspective.

Even though the game is from 2003 its It puts a lot of new games to shame. It's challenging, fun, and has a lot of content.
I recommend.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying, I REALLY tried to like this game. And at first? I loved it. Enclave is an action-based RPG where you hack and slash your way through levels (depending on your class) all while collecting gold so you can afford better gear at a shop you visit in-between levels. Collecting gold is HUGELY important. In later levels archers are OP with their damage and warriors are brutally tanky. You NEED to collect gold otherwise you stand no chance. Let me also state one thing.

THERE IS NO ADWARE IN THIS GAME. THESE MANY REVIEWS THAT SAY SO ARE OLD, AND HAVE NOT CHANGED EVEN THOUGH THE ADWARE HAS BEEN REMOVED.

So what does this game have going for it?
+From 2002 I never would have expected these kinds of graphics.
+The soundtrack is amazing.
+And the sound effects aren't too shabby either.
+The level design and placement of enemies is genius.
+The destruction in this game is fantastic. In buildings during sieges the roof can fall on your head, fatally damaging you. You can slash the beam of a wooden watch tower and bring it falling to the ground. Crates can be broken into flying pieces by explosives that are essentially flying wooden weapons.

UNFORTUNATELY.
-The story is really...bland. A 3 year old that watched lord of the rings could have thought this story up.
-The enemies are very generic and repetitive. Again, a 3 year old that watched lord of the rings could have created these extremely generic characters.
-The voice acting is mediocre.
-The AI is nonsensical is how it acts. Enemies are jumping and breakdancing all over the place while you're supposed to be in a serious fight.
-The combat. The core element of ARPGs, the COMBAT. Is the worst combat I have ever seen in an RPG in my entire life.  Ranged weapons work around a little dot you see in the center of your screen. Place it over an enemy and shoot, and you hit. Miss by an inch and you miss completely. It's pathetic. The melee combat is even worse. You just spam left mouse click to swing a sword aimlessly, missing tiny enemies completely unless you can get down to their level most of the time. Your shield is basically useless because there's a delay between raising it and lowering it that you could have used to get attacks in, that your enemies WILL use to attack you. The swordplay is also very unresponsive. I mouse click twice and suddenly my character is doing a 4-move sword swinging fiasco while I'm right clicking and trying to raise my shield. So an enemy pummels me while my character is having fun being some kind of sword dancer.

Even if you get this for free like I did I would not recommend playing it. Maybe this kind of gameplay was good in an ARPG once, but at the same time, RUNESCAPE had better combat than this. So I could never condone a game that flops on its main element so badly. STAY AWAY.

reviewText:
Enclave is a gem of a game from the original X-Box era back in 2003. Its a third or first person medieval fantasy hack and slash with engaging combat and exceptional environments. For the rogue in all us there is a dark campaign where you play as several evil classes like assassin, berserker, lich and sorceress to name a few. If there are any good hearts out there, you also have the light campaign with their human counterpart classes such as knight, huntress, druid, wizard and half-ling. Each campaign lasted me a fun and joyous seven hours. At the start of each level you select your class and assign their equipment from the money you have. Nothing is permanently bought, so if you want expensive armor and a weak weapon with a few potions, you can do it or if zero potions, expensive weapons and armor is more to your liking go for it. The money is never spent, just assigned. These classes, play styles and different equipment go a long way to making each play through different, even if its your twentieth time on a level.

So why is this game so good? Let's start with the controls and movement. While this was an X-Box game, there doesn't seem to be controller support. You're stuck with your keyboard and rebindable keys. Its more than that though, your character seems to have a good sense of movement. You'll climb ladders, duck to crawl through tunnels, jump up boxes and over collapsed bridges. Even jump from rooftop to rooftop. Each class has its own speed. For the most part the heroes of the light campaign feel slower than their dark counterparts. Knights and berserkers move slow, while half-lings and goblins are the fastest. There is no run button, heroic classes are so slow that it really feels like you need to fight.

Getting there is half the fun, but along the way you'll of course find enemies and you've got the fantastic combat to take them out with. I can't call it deep combat so much as its fun. Each class can have a melee weapon that you really just mouse click bash to flail it around. Each weapon has its own strength, speed and range. Others have enchantments that will light enemies on fire. Most classes also have a shield too. Hold the right mouse button to have your shield up to block arrows and wow you will be blocking a lot of arrows. With some enemies that can fire a shotgun of bolts at you, it becomes mandatory if you're going to survive at close range.

To add some depth there, each time your shield gets bashed, that will knock it away for a split second leaving you open to attack. So if two archers time it just right they can break through your defenses. This goes for enemies with shields too. They're just like you, when their shield is up, you need to knock it down to hurt them.

Wizards, sorceresses, lich and druids have magic. Each magician has a magic meter that refills over time.  So if you run out from fire balling an enemy, you've got to wait, where the enemies see your weakness and will rush at you. You can equip two spell staffs, so you have a variety there in the level. A lot of the spells make the game easier. Plenty of them seek out enemies and turn in the air to hit them. Instead of a shield, the right mouse will raise a force field, but I never used it that much, since mages are such long range classes. Some staffs also have a summoning ability to raise an ally to help you. Oh and the spells can't get blocked. You still take damage.

Form there, non magic classes can also have a long range bow or cross bow. Even the knight and grenaders can use them, but you need to equip them at the start of each level, you can't just find one. I've gotta say crossbows and bows are far too difficult to accurately hit anything. Sure melee enemies running to you will take arrows til they're dead. Its shooting the other archers that becomes incredibly difficult. They can dodge arrows just as good as any human player. Its difficult to accurately hit them, so to compensate, there are several different tricks. You can load several bolts into a bow at once by pressing the right mouse button. Then release so one of them will hit its target if not all to instantly kill a close enemy. There are also fire bolts that will ignite enemies or the ground on fire. The abilities add some interesting facets to the game when you're forced to play as an assassin for the dark campaign's original character.

You have a quick health potion button that really plays into combat, because you need to chug the potion. Its not just instant energy, so if you're getting beaten to death, you need to hide and chug the potion before you can attack or defend again. It adds a lot to the combat and gives the enemies a better chance.

You'll need to unlock the classes as you go through the game. This means you'll be rescuing your comrades in their levels. With them freed, they'll temporarily aide you, fight shoulder to shoulder with you and guide you to the next part. They can die too, but as long as you've saved them and complete the level, they're unlocked.

Enclave puts you into incredible environments and assets are not used from level to level. So each level has a completely different look and feel. Crypts, tombs, caves, castles, lava caverns, shadowy towns, human towns. There is a ton of variety here. Between the light and dark campaigns only a few levels get reused among the two. Even if it is a shared level, you start from the opposite end of it, to make it feel fresher. The levels feel like they're just the right amount of time. Each level has plenty of exploration and a lot of levels feel open enough where you can look around without feeling like you're forced down a corridor. They never overstay their welcome. I never think of it as a chore, because there's always something new and beautiful to see around every corner.

The pre rendered cut scenes and menus are pretty dated with low resolution quality so they don't look as gorgeous as the game itself. Not that the game itself is high definition, but over a decade later it still looks amazing. The only thing lacking are the ground textures. Grassy fields could have used Oblivion style grass, but for a game that came out when Morrowind did it still looks better than its contemporaries.

Its not all roses and sunshine in this dark enchanted world. The game goes from a fun treat and knuckles down on you in later levels to beat you down. I appreciated the challenge, even if some levels took me five minutes to make it across a bridge. If you die, you need to restart the level. To balance it out, if you can make it to a checkpoint, you will respawn there when you die. There's just one catch. You need enough gold collected in that level to respawn. I'm thankful for the checkpoints even at a cost. Having each revive cost gold gives you incentive to return to each level after you complete it. Oh by the way, you only keep the gold if you beat the level. So if you died ten times, you spent one hundred gold, so you can return to the level, not die and get an extra hundred gold to spend. Assuming you collected what you had before. That's the beauty with all the exploration, you can find things or miss them.

You won't get limited to combat, there are some puzzles and a few brief, yet fun turret sections that don't tie you to the turrets. The bosses are giant and feel engaging without being overwhelming or frustrating. A giant dragon, a huge lava monster and the mega evil boss has you shooting its hanging heart. If that wasn't enough for you, there are unlockable mini games that are actually fun. You'll find maps in levels that will unlock games like a survival mode and a cool turret gallery.

The music is also something to take note of. Its great and really fits the medieval epicness of the game. Its beautiful and touching, but with big and bold moments too.

Once again, this is just a gem of a game that I would have paid full price for when it was $50. Thanks to someone from Sweden for giving me the game!

reviewText:
Pros:
+Good graphics, considering it was realeased in 2003
+Nice details, varied environments, some interesting level design
+Story has some cool concepts
+Combat is fun at first
+Good soundtrack
+Low price

Cons:
-Lame RPG elements (no skill progression, just a pick a class, buy the best loadout you can afford, and start mission)
-Missions are painfully linear
-Extremely scripted enemy encounters
-Steep difficulty curve
-No gameplay elements other than platforming and combat
-Combat proves to be awkward/glitchy, and mind-numbingly repetitive
-All fights feel similar after I've beaten several missions
-Missions lack any real replay value (unless you enjoy boring searches for coins)

Enclave is an old action-RPG without the RPG, or any other elements that may have compensated for the lackluster action. Even at a 50% dicount, there are far better and deeper games to spend your $2.49 on than this shallow fantasy title.

If you played it back on Xbox and were able to enjoy it for more than an hour, or otherwise have STRONG reason to believe you would enjoy Enclave's combat, then go ahead and buy it. There are some nice production values here and, apparently, loads of nostalgia throughout. Personally, however, the combat and the gameplay as a whole becomes an endless monotony to the point that I regret my purchase. I hate to thumbs-down a game like this, but I'd be lying through my teeth (or, in this case, my keyboard) if I reccomended Enclave.

This game is something else, truly. For starters it has beautiful graphics for it's time, it look wonderful and you can tell the developers worked really hard on them. The same goes for the weapon and shields, they are very nice to look at, and you feel a sense of accomplishment when you can buy that sword, axe, staff, that completely obliterates your enemies in 2-3 hits.

Now, gameplay, the controls are very solid and quite easy to control. At times it feels the mouse is a tad slow when it comes moving around and viewing everything, but it's easy to adjust in the menu. Also, there is no delay in the buttons so it is very nice.

The fighting is very unispired and makes combat feel more like a chore. After completing the main objective in the quest, towards the end of the game I just bolted out of there. No experience is gained whatsoever, so what's my incentive? Oh, that's right, gold!

Gold, you must collect gold througout the campaign. Some which is hidden VERY well and is extremely UNFAIR to get. When I say unfair, I mean that in this game, there are VERY FEW checkpoints. And if you aim to 100% this, you are going to pull out  your hair. Thing about checkpoints is, if you happen to reach one, but die..you lose gold. And that means you have to start over on the level completely in order to get all gold. Note, you need gold if you want to 100% the guy, buy more items and also  unlock all the characters. Again, it wouldn't be so bad if they weren't in such ridiculous spots. Earlier I said the controls are spot on, which they are, but the way these pots of gold and jewels are placed, it's beyond ridiculous.

Storyline, it was very meh. You don't connect the chracters at all and the cutscenes and whatnot are very short and semi-informative. Really starting to show its age.

Enclave is an RPG where you can play both as the good guys and the bad guys in two different campaigns. Its story is slightly boring and not very insteresting, failing to pull me in at all.

You also die at random events if you don't watch your every step and checkpoints are pretty few and far between.

Graphics are average for its age, nothing special to write home about. The levels are neat, being pretty full and there is room for exploration.

5$ isn't what I would pay for it, wait until its on sale for a dollar or two, but even then I would just put that money towards a better 5$ game.

The graphics are old but they dont hurt the eye or anything. The basic premise of the game is to go around various dungeons, kill stuff, collect gold to buy items and do the next dungeon.  I really wouldnt consider this a RPG, as there is no real role play, its an action game, and a pretty decent one at that.

The story is simple;  bad guys coming to kill you.. kill them before they can kill you.  And the dark campaign is basically the same, except youre the baddy.

Its pretty for its age, it has some nice environments and nicely done mechanics. A good example of these mechanics would be the halfling lady. Shes too short to be hit with certain  attacks, so shes good when facing certain enemies.  I know this may sound broken, but its pretty obvious its intentional.

Enclave is a game that has a refreshing level of difficulty as well. If you die, and dont have a checkpoint, you restart from the beginning. If you do have a checkpoint activated, it costs 10 gold to bring you back. I never died enough to lose all of my money so I dont know what happens then.  Alot of the complaints about the difficulty are from people who did not get far enough in to get the checkpoints.


Really the only issues I had with the game, is that its rather short, and linear, and the fact that its labeled an RPG when it barely has RPG elements to it. Its an action game 100%. That being said its worth it, especially if its on sale!

The game itself is about medieval-style hack and slash game with a great graphic (from 2002 timeline perspective).

I tried to like this game but.... somehow i felt something missing from the game while playing it, something that should be exist in game, enjoyment.

I know it's subjective matter about enjoyment, but even an old game like Crash Team Racing can give me enjoyment while playing it better than this game.

Pros :
+ Great and enticing graphic from 2002 game
+ Nice UI game
+ Smooth even in low spec PC (why can't this implemented in any other games? Dev?)
+ Many weapons and armors choices

Cons :
- THE STORY, it's so bland and so obvious. Something that makes this game can't meet its expectation

- Combat system and movement is so dull from 3D perspective. Should make it 2D side scrolling instead
- Not too intelligent Artificial Intelligent (AI)

Still, i can't recommend this game for who seeks a great story based hack-and-slash game (because the game itself is trying to be one).

4/10 because bland story and dull combat movement.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B0mGH27bNuU

I didn't finish the game, so keep that in mind

Have you ever wanted to like a game, that looks fun and you hope it really is, but in the end you got bored and never finish it? I'm sure you have. This is the case with Enclave for me. After 6 h (around half of the game, I think) I just stop playing it. The game is not bad, but few things I don't like, contribute for my boredom.

For such an old game it have a lot of video options. Resolution, separated menus for graphics and textures, sliders for sound and music and even syncing with refresh rate. Last but not least, you can rebind keys, use a controller, on and of damage number indicator and so on. But make no mistake, the game is ugly, but not unbearably ugly. Graphics didn't age very well, textures are bad, enemies tends to jump really high, levels don't have enough details, but it's an old game, so it's expected.

The story is simple – you have to save the world and it is the worst part of the game. There somewhat interesstig backstory, but the developer didn't capitalized the fun premise. In the end, one can say it is absent. Even other reviews pointed this. It is cliché fantasy story, not develop enough.

So, next is gameplay. It is where I had some fun and there is a lot to talk about. Here you can find some interesting ideas – character classes and fighting system. Let's dive in.

The game have two campaigns – Light and Dark. As far as my knowledge, first you have to start with the Light and beat it to unlock the Dark. Enclave is hack 'n slash third-person action game with options for first-person, focusing on strategic combat for melee classes. If you enter thinking that this is similar to Devil May Cry or Dynasty Warriors, you will be killed really fast. The combat is slow and methodical. I think the best comparison is Dark Souls, but probably not that hard. Your shield is valuable as much as your weapons. The game is tough, but I can say with some patience every challenge can be overcome. The character you start is a Knight class. He is using melee weapons primarily. When you enter a battle, it's with your shield raised. You have to keep track of enemy hit patterns to find when is the best time to strike. You have to be patience. Interesting thing here is that size matters. What I mean is you may raise your shield, but your feet and head are not protected. You have to consider where to put it. In the beginning you will encounter short imp-like creatures and lowering the shield is crucial and vice versa. If your characters is short, taller enemies are easy. You can even use the terrain at your advantage, if you manage to get the enemy on higher ground. When using a melee weapon you can do a three hit combo and with every hit your damage increase, but it leaves open for attack. So, it's up to you to decide do more damage or hit once and bring up the shield. It's risk-reward situation. Depending on your movement, you make a different swing with the weapon and this add to the strategic gameplay.

Through the most of my play time, I used the Knight class. At some point I decide to see the other classes. What I found is range classes are boring. The combat with them is like any other third-person shooter and they weren't interesting as melee classes.

Every character have a melee and range weapon, but depending on the class, they are specialize in certain play style, so don't expect Knight class, for example, to get the best range weapons and vice versa. And speaking of classes, they are total of 12, but you don't get them right away, you will unlock them by playing the game. I don't like that. Why? What is the point of that? Unlock them from the beginning. But there is one interesting thing about that. You don't level up by getting XP. You just have to gatter gold for new gear. And since this is the case, the dev decide after each level, for all unlocked classes, you will get additional money, so you can swap character before entering a level and not playing the whole game again. New gear is unlocked by beating a level. This is all it required. They don't have statistic, so i assume, if it's cost more, it's better. Weapons include swords, crossbows, maces, bows, axes and so on. Some classes have can equip additional stuff like bombs, different types of arrows and so on.

One of the things I don't like is the AI. I feel enemies can walk only in a straight line and when get the chance I use this the get them to suicide or to stuck in the environment. The other thing is range enemies. Their projectiles can go through solid surfaces and it was annoying. The third things is the level design. Building after building after building. There are some places like vulcano and small harbor town. Although their design is somewhat diverse, in the end I find it boring and not very inspired.

Enemies are not very creative. Small imp-like creatures, orc without armor, orcs with armor and shield, big ogres, spell casting enemy and so on. But most disappointg are the bosses. I only saw two. They also have uninspired design and they are boring to fight.

Sound design is meh. Noting to remember. Music feels like typical for fantasy game, sound fx are okay and the voice acting is average. Don't expect something groundbreaking or something to remember here.

I'm somewhere in the middle about this game. Although old, there is something to see, something to enjoy. Melee characters are worth playing in my opinion. Everything else is like sound and level design, some of the classes, the AI are average and story – completely forgetable. I couldn't bring my self the finish the whole game. I almost reach half of the journey and got bored, so take my opinion with a pinch of salt. Nothing exciting happened during my time with the game. There is enough here that pushed me away, but it still have my cautious recommendation. Get it on sale. Why I recommend it? Because I can see something that others might enjoy, but not me. Melee classes have more interesting play style, than the others. The game is not garbage, I had some fun, but there is nothing here that could hold my attention for a long period of time. Maybe someday I will revist it to see if I can enjoy it more and finish it.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
It is medieval fantasy TPP hack-n-slash with bits of platforming actions.

Looks decent and level design lets you have some fun looking for hidden treasures. But fighting is boring. Like really boring. It just doesnt work at all. And as for h-n-s it is major issue so nothing can save this game.

On the bright side game has two nice 'twists' that could interest somebody.

First is multiple of characters to play as. During missions you can meet some NPCs in trouble and if you manage to save them they will join you and act as playable characters for the rest of the game. On the other hand this undefined main character causes story to be unrelated to characters. So dont expect any story from this game. Just almost random stages, enemies and your character of choice. It could be arena-type game and it wouldnt be any different.

Next 'twist' is that you can outfit your hero before every mission. Equipping your character is based on limited budget mechanic. Every piece of gold you collected adds to the pool of gold which limits gear you can wear. Every piece of equipment substracts from this pool so you have to pick if you prefer balanced setup with average elements or maybe you will sacrifice armor in favor of better weapon. You cant pick your playstyle and enjoy the game your way without being forced to play some fixed archetype.
Mentioned gold you receive for completing every mission and even more you can find during the mission as extra hidden treasures that require from you taking extra risk. And risk here is high - death equals restart of the level. But thats fine, levels are short and fun part is mastering every level.

To sum it up: game is quite interesting and as such curiosity you could grab it to have a look, but i was unable to finish it - simplistic fighting mechanics are boring and no amount of customisation of character can change that.

reviewText:
I already owned the game before I added it to Steam. For the time it was made the graphics were amazing and still hold their weight  today. Textures are crisp and I can play this game at 1080p with no issue, the only downside is FoV is locked, though at 95 it isn't that bad.

Story progression is ok. Light vs Dark and a rift that divides both. Unfortunately the rift is shrinking and both sides are now butting heads. I only wish the characters you meet in playing through the game had at least some back story or names, rather than just Warrior, Druid, Halfling, etc..

Combat is fine. Melee combat offers 3 weapon classes, Sword, Axe and Hammer.  Melee weapons also have some form of a combo in where if you swing successively 3 times it produces an end effect. Bows offer a wide range of ammunition from sniper bolts which lets you zoom in at far away targets, standard bolts that allow you to stack them up for a burst shot, fire bolts for damage over time, and explosive bolts for aoe damage. Crossbows are your medium ranged weapon and can be used by both ranged and melee classes. Staffs used by your mages offer a standard attack, close ranged aoe attack, and a shield to block melee and ranged hits.

Character customization goes as far as how much gold you've collected in your play through. Gold acts a point system and it's scattered throughout the game world, some in pots and others in the form of gems.  The more gold you've collected the better things you can equip. This can range from better armor, weapons, shields, staffs, more ammo for bows, etc... I would say your bow users as well as your engineers/bombardiers are more demanding in gold requirements due to how much stuff they can equip while other classes like warriors don't require much at all. Gold you've collected stays with you for your entire progression. Also collecting it all awards something special in the end.

The only sad part about this game is there's no multiplayer, which at the time would have been great as it looks like it could have supported at least 4 players (Just judging by the wave levels in the campaign). All in all it's a good game.

I also still hope for an Enclave 2.

That was 11 years ago. Now that I've revisited it, it's a great looking game still, despite all this time, the fighting system isn't the best but the variety of weapons and classes available still makes this game great fun. The story is somewhat weak but for those who haven't played it before, there's enough story to keep you going. Once you finish the light campaign you can replay the game from the bad guy's perspective!

Pros:
•	Visually very impressive.
•	2 complete storylines.
•	Wide range of weapons.
Cons:
•	A lack of direction for the story, it's more of a hack and slash.
•	No character progression.

reviewText:
7/10 - An enclave you'll not regret to visit.

Got this game in a bundle and what a pleasant surprise!

Everything about this game is retro in the best possible way. The map design, the models, the graphics, the effects - it all has that 00s charm from games that made the best out of technical limitations.

++PROS++

+The maps are actually pretty small but with every design trick in the book (the one still used for Half-Life maps) you can run around quite long until you've been to every corner. Maps are very diverse from temples, dungeons and caves over castles and even whole villages but due to the small size there are no wilderness areas.

+Combat is rather demanding with melee weapons, bows and spells. Everytime you thought you found a working routine a new kind of enemy or tactical situation makes you throw it over board again.

+There is a lot of action apart from combat, your character can swim, dive, jump ledges, climb ladders, and pull levers. There are several TR-like puzzles and on occassion you can use physics to kill enemies.

+The menu is simple and accessbile and the controls work properly most of the time.

+You get additional characters along the way (who sometimes accompany you in the maps you find them) and you can choose for each new map which cahracter should tackle it

--CONS--

-The game is completely railroaded. Everytime you finish a map,a new one gets available.

- Some of the characters you get to use are pretty useless

- The range of equipment (different for most characters) is very underwhelming and there is actually not much choice how a character is equipped at every stage of the game

- Sound effects are not good, Mostly a torch or waterfall is as loud in the next room as it was standing in front of it only to vanish completely once you're far away enough.

- After a dozen maps or so it gets a little repetetive, I admit I haven't played it to the end.

All in all I had a lot of fun and I can recommend it as one of the games to can play if you just have an hour or two and want some fast&fun action in between.

reviewText:
I already owned the game before I added it to Steam. For the time it was made the graphics were amazing and still hold their weight  today. Textures are crisp and I can play this game at 1080p with no issue, the only downside is FoV is locked, though at 95 it isn't that bad.

Story progression is ok. Light vs Dark and a rift that divides both. Unfortunately the rift is shrinking and both sides are now butting heads. I only wish the characters you meet in playing through the game had at least some back story or names, rather than just Warrior, Druid, Halfling, etc..

Combat is fine. Melee combat offers 3 weapon classes, Sword, Axe and Hammer.  Melee weapons also have some form of a combo in where if you swing successively 3 times it produces an end effect. Bows offer a wide range of ammunition from sniper bolts which lets you zoom in at far away targets, standard bolts that allow you to stack them up for a burst shot, fire bolts for damage over time, and explosive bolts for aoe damage. Crossbows are your medium ranged weapon and can be used by both ranged and melee classes. Staffs used by your mages offer a standard attack, close ranged aoe attack, and a shield to block melee and ranged hits.

Character customization goes as far as how much gold you've collected in your play through. Gold acts a point system and it's scattered throughout the game world, some in pots and others in the form of gems.  The more gold you've collected the better things you can equip. This can range from better armor, weapons, shields, staffs, more ammo for bows, etc... I would say your bow users as well as your engineers/bombardiers are more demanding in gold requirements due to how much stuff they can equip while other classes like warriors don't require much at all. Gold you've collected stays with you for your entire progression. Also collecting it all awards something special in the end.

The only sad part about this game is there's no multiplayer, which at the time would have been great as it looks like it could have supported at least 4 players (Just judging by the wave levels in the campaign). All in all it's a good game.

I also still hope for an Enclave 2.

reviewText: The combat in this game is very clunky and simple. There's no real strategy to it, you just run up and spam left click to do your combos. You can use a shield but it isn't very useful since it doesn't knock an enemy back when they hit it or stun them. You will often find your strikes missing even though you can clearly see that your weapon hit the enemy. Just assume that your weapon is always half as long as it looks to be. Your enemies are also usually just as fast if not faster than you. Once they get close there's no escaping them, they'll stick to you like a tick until you kill them. That can be pretty annoying when you have to fight groups of enemies at once. I got this for 59 cents and for its time I can see that it would have been a good game but melee combat has become more complex since then. It all feels very dated and is honestly pretty boring.

reviewText:
Encalve is a great game for what it is - an action focussed Hack and Slash. There's no character development but you find money on levels which you can buy better gear with. This creates a cool puzzle/platform element as it's no easy task to find it all as there are some very interesting places the money is stored.

I played this a lot years ago and on the hardest difficulty it will give you a run for your money. It's of an older vein of games that will be frustrating at first as you need to place arrows carefully and time your swings exactly or you'll be flailing around hitting nothing.

2 Campaigns with plenty of replayability due to around 6 different characters for both the light and dark faction. They basically mirror each other - so there's a warrior/archer/wizard/engineer/etc for both factions. Each character requires a different play style as you can imagine and get some unique equipment that you can buy.

I was pretty excited that this was on discount on steam - 47p or thereabouts. However I've only been playing about 30 mins and the game crashed on the second level. Tried again and crashed right at the end again. Very frustrating -- and I imagine all support for the game will be gone now so no hope of a fix. The error message only flashed up for a brief second so apologise for not giving the exact error. Hopefully it's just me but worth bearing in mind if you're paying full price.

For what is a game you'll easily get 40 hours playtime out of, it's a shame that the steam version seems a little unstable.

The game itself is a solid 7/10

reviewText:
One of these great games underated you should play at least 'cause of action/adventure gameplay basis it founded !
It's a well managed port of an 1st & 3rd person action rpg xbox game... To be honest, this pc version has way better optimized graphics and controls than this last one. Kinda précious thing i could estimate while todays developers are not getting confortable with pc for mercantile and pessimistic reasons.


Graphics are clearly outdated from nowadays, lots of clipping, little bit tearing when speeding up camera movement, global cubic rendering but it also works like a charm. Textures are clean even if obsolete and non-HD designed. The game offers quite a few graphical settings very pleasant for a console port.
Generally, the good quality  level design and architecture serves the medieval fantastic ambiance, environments are inspired and never get redundant. Levels stay linear but some of them are very wide-open ans submited to a labyrinthine path, so it's easy to walk round while you are looking tirelessly for a wood key that will bring you to the next room.

Gameplay is very interesting and fun. As you complete levels , the game gives ability to unlock and play characters with its own skills, and retribute you with coins you gather during the mission. Indeed, before each mission, a menu lets users spend budget in new weapons such as enchanted crossbows, tremendous magical swords, big boom bombs, powerful magical sticks, warrior armors,... Each of these new supplies has a certain cost and doing the cupid globetrotter roaming through the entire level will make you quickly one of the best bashing champions all over the enclave.
In game, controls are very reactive but aiming is a little bit buggy ; the shots given by your character don't reach ennemy each time you wanna touch its, in fact lots of shots with no damage are expected.The game has a very hard feeling mostly because of this part of the gameplay. It remains thought fairy difficult and at any moment, it become nonsense of frustration as demon's souls can be often.

Soundtrack is a classical variety of dark medieval themes and participates in making the ambiance immersive. However, it is repetitive to hear all the same themes for differents levels so It doesn't offer necessarily an audio consistency to each level that make this boring and annoying after hours. Vocal dubbing is correct, voices actors are convinient despite conviction missing for some of them.

Two campaigns : light and darkness... Very cute and original. Player start first with the light campaign which has a storyline better exploited, longer and devoided with narrative ellipses instead of dark campaign less rich lingering on crucial moments that can be rapidly sent over.

Now it's your turn to save people of the light and/or darkness... And kill them above all, that's the real purpose and leitmotiv of this outlet epic game !

reviewText:
A solid hack and slash game.  Simple enough to jump into and play, complex enough to keep things interesting throughout.  This game was originally designed to be a PVP game, however it was developed into a strictly PVE game.  But, you can still see remnants of it's PVP origins.  Enemies can do anything you can do, the engine feels very quake-like and old school.  In this sense, it's completely balanced, aside from the fact that the bad guys outnumber you and can have stronger gear.  You acquire new gear throughout the game by collecting a set amount of gold from each mission (which are replayable, in case you missed any of the set amount.  Ex: 290/300).  Most of the gold is found via secrets, which I find quite enjoyable.  Some of them are quite clever, too.  It's definitely old school, bringing back memories of Duke and Doom secrets.  Mappers have even left their mark on the maps, if you are clever enough to find them.

Now let's talk about the bad.  This game has aged, really poorly.  I played this game back in the early 2000's, back when everything worked.  Some serious tuneups have to be done with the engine or something.  Perhaps the community can find some workarounds for a lot of these things.  Sometimes the game runs at hyper speed; the hitboxes are all wacked, meaning I will miss half the time for some odd reason, and I have to be very particular about which attack I use and when to time it, because most other attacks don't land; moving my mouse makes me move super fast, but none of the game speeds up with it; and there are just general crashes.

The game is still playable, but it does become really hard to enjoy what was once a pretty solid and good game, due to it no longer working on modern machines.  If some work was done with the game, it would be great.  I'll still recommend it, because of what it was, and what it could be, given some patches and fixes.  We'll see what happens in the future.

reviewText:
Enclave is one of those old-school games from back in the day, from times that are now forever gone. It won't come up as a surprise for you, that this title has no DLC microtransactions or an insane amount of senseless grinding, instead being a true type of an adventure RPG with solid, fun gameplay. In the most accurate sense, Enclave is more of a hack-and-slash action rather than a RPG, although roleplaying elements are definetely present in this game. Despite being released way back in 2002, Enclave still manages to thrill and entertain even today, in large part thanks to its graphical quality and a relatively well created atmosphere.

In terms of the plotline, Enclave is your typical dark fantasy, where the ever encroaching darkness is about to swarm the last remains of hope... literally. Long ago, a great demon waged war against all that is good in order to destroy it, but in the process of doing so, he got slain. This event shattered the face of the planet, and the last hope of victorious men is now but a single stranded kingdom, known as the Enclave. After many years, those who were once loyal to the demon yet again are now ready to kill and destroy, and it seems that the demon himself is about to reincarnate back into the grim of world of Enclave. Without going too far into the details of the story, it can be noted, that even though the storyline  is kind of average, it still gets the job done and keeps the player hooked. Every single mission in the game has a very unique environment, ranging from trap filled tombs and lava sizzling valleys to strange places of mystical power. There are two campaings in Enclave, allowing you to try yourself out in both the roles of a hero in a not so shining armor, or an ugly looking baddie with an amusing, albeit not a quite threatening appearance. Old timers that played such games as Heretic II or Arx Fatalis will love Enclave, although the two mentioned titles are still ofcourse different in many ways.

Throughout the game, your arsenal will include alot of melee and ranged weapons. Melee arms consist of various swords, clubs and axes, ranged weaponry consists of bows and magical staves. In terms of protection, your heroes will have three types of armor and alot of shields. Usually, as one would guess, the most expensive type of protection and weaponry is the most effective one, and as the game progressesess, you will be able to equip your heroes with the best type of gear, if ofcourse you collect gold and valuable gems that are scattered throughtout missions. Otherwise, you will have to play as a raggedy orc or a cloth-clad gnome. Battles are usually straightforward, especially when it comes to melee. Most of the time, you will try to deal a blow to the enemy while protecting yourself with a shield. Ranged duels with bows are more thrilling, and so are the fights between mages. In terms of combat and gameplay in general, Enclave is an entertaining game, just the kind of a game to relax with after work or study. The missions are challening, but at the same time are not annoying. From time to time, cinematics with explanation to the background lore will keep the players entertained and focused, and the music that is present in the game is pretty good and atmospheric.

In a summary, it can be written, that Enclave is a game worth to be recommended. Without a doubt, time has taken its toll on the game, and some younger, more demanding players might not like it, but if you are not too critical when it comes to older titles, and if you enjoy a good action game, Enclave is for you.

P.S: Very often Enclave gets sold on Steam for a discount at a price of approximately 80 cents. If you have the patience and if you are really strapped for cash but nonetheless want to play this game, just wait for a discount, and you can purchase it for almost nothing :D

reviewText:
Before you make your descision on buying it or not it is VERY IMPORTANT to know that this game came out in over 10 years ago, in 2003(?), meaning that if you need your fix for high graphics, walk away now. It's not that they are bad or are comparable to a game like Nidhogg, however you are able to see it's age by all of the flat and repeating textures, lack of any anti alising and even a few very pixely items.

It also has to be mentioned that the menus do not have mouse support, meaning you have to use the arrow keys, Enter and Esc to navigate the menus.

That being said Enclave can be a fairly fun experience if you enjoy it's combat and exploration, the only problem being that the combat is very simple, somewhat cluncky and even unreliable as far as the hitboxes go when it comes to using ranged weapons close up to enemies. No matter who you choose to play as (will be explained upon better later in the review) it feels like an M1 spam fest as that is your only way of attacking with your sword/axe/hammer/dagger. Your other other ways of doing damage is (depending on the character) by pulling out your crossbow/bow/staff, and pressing M1. For it's time it was OK however in a day and age where we have a long list of games with numerous abilities and ways of doing damage, Enclave begins to show it's age. Though it has to be said that the combat is fairly satisfying. When you pull off a combo (depending on the weapon, M1 x Type Of Melee Weapon) the last hit will do double damage, and even give the attack splash damage so any nearby enemy will also take damage. This alone isn't much, but paired with a nice 'smashing' sound and a little bit of screen shake, it truely does feel good when you finish off multiple enemies with your final swing.

Exploration is a different story, whereas the age of Enclave has been hurting it, Enclave shows how older games did their exploration and it made you want to explore the land you were put in. When you start a mission you are put inside a medium/large sized area where there are a number of pickups that will become extremely important in your journey through each level, and ultimately the game itself. You will come across ammo pick ups for your crossbow/bow (may you have one on you or not), health potions, checkpoints and even gold. The health potions and ammo are given and taken away on a mission by mission basis, where you can find 3 potions in a mission, however they will be taken away after the mission is over.

The gold on the other hand is collected and kept for a equipment screen you will use before each mission. When you select your mission, you will be given the option of who you want to use for that mission. Each character has their own loadout (the Druid is the only one who can use staffs, etc.) that you can fill up, which is where the gold comes into play. You use the gold as more of a borrowing system then a buying system seeing as you choose your items from the equipment screen by just swapping through them, taking or returning gold depending on the quaility/quantity of the item. An easier way of thinking of it is by switching out gold with a weight system. Instead of gaining +5 gold, you picked up +5 max weight, allowing you to use better/more weapons/armour/ammo/health potions. The better equipment comes back to help you complete more difficult missions and get more gold.

If you enjoyed playing through the game once then you will be very happy to know that there are actually TWO campaigns to Enclave, the Light side where you face the forces of evil, and a more difficult Dark campaign where you face the forces of good. Besides that there are hoard mode missions on both sides of of the game where you face increasingly difficult groups of enemies to gain gold for the main missions and other hoard missions. These missions can be found by finding maps in the main missions which will open up a new spot on the mission select screen.

All in all, Enclave can be a fun game if you can get past the fact that it's over 10 years old and has nearly everything that comes with it being old. Personally I wouldn't buy it for $5.00 US dollars, but if you can get it while it's on sale (75%+), then I would recommend giving it at least an hour of your time just so you can at least experience what Enclave has to offer. It's not a bad game, it's just dated.

reviewText:
If you look for a good RPG/ARPG or Hack-n-slash - you've taken a wrong turn.

First and only reason why is game is not even remotely worth your attention - this is a bad port from original xbox game.

1) There's no proper gamepad support, at least I didn't manage to make it usable with both x-input and d-input. What make matters worse - game doesn't react to keyboard keys bound to gamepad buttons, so I had to stick with mouse + KB. And yes, you cannot use mouse in main menu (makes sense since it's a console game in first place).
2) The gameplay itself constantly suffers from random camera spins, random teleportation of your character and sometimes illogical reaction to commands - it can react slowly to button presses, it can execute your attacks way faster than usual. Hitboxes are quite off as well, in fact they are so off from visuals that it's obvious just a few minutes into the game.

I see no point in describing the gameplay itself since I didn't see much, the only thing I can point out is that the combat is really too simple and narrows down to some kind of hit-n-run M1 spam, ranged weapons are almost unusable due to technical issues described earlier. Character development is also pretty much non-existent. Probably was okay for 2003, but now I'd not recommend playing it.

recommended:

reviewText:
Fun Hack and Slash action adventure with that certain Conan the Barbarian fantasy pulp feel.

Evil is afoot or whatever so you kill stuff. Theres no leveling, you pick up gold in the levels which after completion gets added to a total you use to not really but kinda buy and sell - its more of a point limit you get to spend on equipment. For example with 100 gold you could equip a sword and armor for both 50 or a bow for 100. Theres usually one checkpoint each level (no quicksaves) and dieing means losing 10 gold - if you manage to find the checkpoint, else game over.

Theres multiple character types to unlock altho some are just straight upgrades (in one case not strangely).

Levels are well designed and varied, for such an old game it really looks amazing if you put all the sliders to the right. Gameplaywise it starts out abit slow but picks up pace along with higher difficulty.

Melee fighting is rather simplistic tho, you can block and do a 3 strike combo. Something seems off with hitboxes, i had attacks whiff which really should have connected, this is especially noticeable using bows and such in very close range, shots pass right thru enemies if you dont aim at their feet or in first person. Annyoing but workable.

Other minor cons:
- very crashy if not in XP compatibility mode which breaks the steam overlay
- rename or delete install.vdf in the reg folder in the games folder or have a steam store page for some ♥♥♥♥ open each time you start this

If you remember Severance: Blade of Darkness - this is kinda a lite version. Good fun, recommended.

reviewText:
I'd give this a 7/10.
I used to play this game on Xbox like 10 years ago and I have to say, its better on PC. I never completed it on the Xbox but its looking hopeful for me now on the computer. I never particularly liked the melee characters because the melee fighting system is a bit flaily and wavy (for lack of better words), you will understand what I mean if you decide to play it. Now ranged is where it is at: it is rather satisfying pinging an enemy from a while back and scoring crit damage on them in the game as there is no auto aim function to speak of (apart from some of the staffs the wizards/druids/lichs wield). Due to the nature of an analogue stick, this is rather difficult but using a PC and mouse makes it actually really fun.
Other stuff: storyline isnt engaging so don't buy it for that; graphics are good for their time but nothing amazing although they do offer a nice visual diversitah; music is great but I swear there is like 4 soundtracks (eg. wandering around music, cinematic music, battle music, and menu music); replayability is evident because of gold hunting/exploring or just thrashing a level with characters with bossing equipment (which is always fun); the game is actually challenging rather than just a case of grinding (which is the case with alot of games nowadays); the game's size is applaudible for how easy it is to run on modern computers.
In addition: its £4! Bargain for a game to pass the time when your internet is down; surprisingly addictive; great when your baked and when COD or DOTA is too much for you at that time.
Highly recommend. Even if you dont trust this review, its four pounds. Whats to lose?

The Verdict - A Polished Turd.
Visuals and sound aside, I found little to actually enjoy from the gameplay. If you like this style of this game, go and play Risen, Gothic or Two Worlds instead... They are superior titles.

reviewText:
I was genuinely surprised when I picked this up for $0.94. First of all, after looking at the graphics in the screenshots, I was shocked to read this game is from 2003. The graphics are absolutely wonderful for its time, and even don't look half bad by today's standards; the fact that 1920x1080 is a supported resolution is just icing on the cake. (only the game textures support 1080p though, so the backgrounds look horrendus.) It reminded me a bit of the Champions series mixed with The Witcher.

The combat feels satisfying, aside from the stiffness and slight repetition; timing your blocks and blows is very immersive and can make you forget how clunky other aspects of the game can be.

All that being said, there is a slight problem with misdirection; this can be justified a bit because a lot of games from this time didn't exactly hold your hand, but there were times when I had no idea what to do, and only when I backtracked (or maybe just moved on to an identical area; I don't know), did the game move forward. Certain NPCs don't follow you when they should and seem to have the ability to teleport if you don't stay right on them.

All in all, I'd say it's worth the $0.94 I paid for it, though I don't know as if I would have bought it at full price. It's certainly worth a play, and it's enjoyable enough to justify the price, even if you only play it a few times.

tl;dr: Can be misleading at times, but the combat and graphics are nice.
